title: The past three years for Laurentian Bank of Canada (TSE:LB) investors has not been profitable
description: In order to justify the effort of selecting individual stocks, it's worth striving to beat the returns from a market...
content:
In order to justify the effort of selecting individual stocks, it's worth striving to beat the returns from a market index fund. But the risk of stock picking is that you will likely buy under-performing companies. We regret to report that long term Laurentian Bank of Canada (TSE:LB) shareholders have had that experience, with the share price dropping 25% in three years, versus a market return of about 47%.

Now let's have a look at the company's fundamentals, and see if the long term shareholder return has matched the performance of the underlying business.

Trump has pledged to "unleash" American oil and gas and these 15 US stocks have developments that are poised to benefit.

While markets are a powerful pricing mechanism, share prices reflect investor sentiment, not just underlying business performance. One way to examine how market sentiment has changed over time is to look at the interaction between a company's share price and its earnings per share (EPS).

Laurentian Bank of Canada became profitable within the last five years. We would usually expect to see the share price rise as a result. So given the share price is down it's worth checking some other metrics too.

We note that the dividend seems healthy enough, so that probably doesn't explain the share price drop. Revenue has been pretty flat over three years, so that isn't an obvious reason shareholders would sell. So it might be worth looking at how revenue growth over time, in greater detail.

You can see below how earnings and revenue have changed over time (discover the exact values by clicking on the image).

We know that Laurentian Bank of Canada has improved its bottom line lately, but what does the future have in store? So it makes a lot of sense to check out what analysts think Laurentian Bank of Canada will earn in the future (free profit forecasts).

It is important to consider the total shareholder return, as well as the share price return, for any given stock. The TSR is a return calculation that accounts for the value of cash dividends (assuming that any dividend received was reinvested) and the calculated value of any discounted capital raisings and spin-offs. Arguably, the TSR gives a more comprehensive picture of the return generated by a stock. We note that for Laurentian Bank of Canada the TSR over the last 3 years was -9.1%, which is better than the share price return mentioned above. This is largely a result of its dividend payments!

Laurentian Bank of Canada's TSR for the year was broadly in line with the market average, at 21%. Most would be happy with a gain, and it helps that the year's return is actually better than the average return over five years, which was 8%. Even if the share price growth slows down from here, there's a good chance that this is business worth watching in the long term. While it is well worth considering the different impacts that market conditions can have on the share price, there are other factors that are even more important. Case in point: We've spotted 1 warning sign for Laurentian Bank of Canada you should be aware of.
summary: The past three years for Laurentian Bank of Canada (TSE:LB) investors have seen a 25% drop in share price in three years, compared to a market return of 47%. This is due to the company's long-term shareholder return matching the performance of the underlying business. Share prices reflect investor sentiment, not just business performance, as well as the interaction between a company's share price and its earnings per share (EPS) over time. The company became profitable within the last five years, which is usually expected to lead to a rise in the share price. However, given the current share price is down, it is worth checking other metrics such as the dividend and revenue growth. The future of LaurentianBank of Canada is also considered by experts to be considered.
shortSummary: Laurentian Bank of Canada investors face a 25% share price drop due to poor underlying business performance, which may be explained through dividends or market returns.

About the Company
| Founded | Employees | CEO | Website |
|---|---|---|---|
| 1846 | 2,800 | Eric Provost | www.laurentianbank.ca |
Laurentian Bank of Canada, together with its subsidiaries, provides various financial services to personal, business, and institutional customers in Canada and the United States. It operates through Personal Banking and Commercial Banking, and the Capital Markets segments. The company offers checking, current, savings, and other accounts; personal line of credit; personal, student, short and long term, and business loans; equipment financing; equipment and inventory financing; credit cards; and mortgages.

Results
22
Midstream oil and gas companies, specifically pipeline operators, are well-positioned to benefit from Trump’s executive orders on fossil fuels enacted in early 2025. – – These policies aim to accelerate infrastructure development by streamlining environmental reviews and permitting processes, such as those under the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA). The declaration of a "national energy emergency" further empowers these companies by prioritizing pipeline and storage projects to support increased production from newly accessible federal lands and waters. – – The push to "unleash American energy" also amplifies demand for midstream services as upstream production ramps up, particularly in regions like Alaska and offshore areas reopened for drilling. Pipelines and storage facilities will be critical to moving larger volumes of oil and gas efficiently, especially with the renewed emphasis on LNG exports to meet global demand.

argos_summary: Laurentian Bank of Canada’s share price has fallen 25% over three years, lagging the market’s 47% return, yet its total shareholder return of –9.1% is less negative thanks to a healthy dividend stream.  The bank’s fundamentals show flat revenue but improving earnings, a modest 6.8% projected earnings growth and 4.1% revenue growth, while its return on equity is expected to stay low at about 5.7%.  Despite a solid dividend, the bank’s share price performance and volatility remain below the Canadian banking sector average, and analysts flag limited upside potential.  The article also notes that Trump’s 2025 fossil‑fuel policies are boosting midstream oil and gas companies, listing 22 firms that could benefit from accelerated pipeline and LNG infrastructure projects.
